Peter Czipott -- Here you are.

Mark R. Rank & Thomas A. Hirschl ... "looked at 44 years of longitudinal data regarding individuals from ages 25 to 60 to see what percentage of the American population would experience these different levels of affluence during their lives. The results were striking."
"It turns out that 12 percent of the population will find themselves in the top 1 percent of the income distribution for at least one year. What’s more, 39 percent of Americans will spend a year in the top 5 percent of the income distribution, 56 percent will find themselves in the top 10 percent, and a whopping 73 percent will spend a year in the top 20 percent of the income distribution."
- See more at: http://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2014/04/mobility-in-and...

Dick Springer:

Power is respected, weakness is ridiculed. Bush had a higher approval rating in Arab countries than Obama, because they knew Bush had power, and they see that Obama doesn't.

You may not like what Putin did in Crimea, but I can assure you that he is respected (and feared) in many countries that see the USA as a declining, powerless shell of itself. If a country threatens to use chemical weapons and Obama and Putin say they won't allow it, which president do you think they will give more weight to?

I lived through the Vietnam war and the Carter presidency; I can tell you that the mood of the country today is very much like it was after Carter: depressed, defeated and feeling no hope for the future.  The good news is that a strong, positive president like Ronald Reagan with a clear vision and a firm foreign policy can turn things around.
Indeed - the picture is worth more than a thousand words of Obama!
You can tell that without any knowledge of what was being said at the time?  But what was the meaning behind the necklace she was wearing?  Surely that must mean something?

I distinctly remember watching this live. Obama was talking about telephone wire tapping. Check out the transcript, and following his little spiel on it, Merkel directly refuted what Obama had said.

CHANCELLOR MERKEL: (As interpreted.) I think the whole debate has shown that the situation is such that we have a few difficulties yet to overcome.

http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/05/02/remarks-president-...
Take a look at the expression on Chancellor Merkel's face in the accompanying picture.  It is a combination of anger, disgust and nausea. There is no respect there.
I am glad you admit that Obama is just another 'sharp talker', hits it right on the head.  Best to just tune him out after all he is always 'just getting to the bottom of the matter'.

After nearly a decade, when we embarked on two wars while cutting taxes, we hear the familiar refrain from those who call for a "strong president" with a "firm foreign policy like Ronald Reagan."

Except Ronald Reagan was nothing but a blusterer and sharp talker when it came to foreign policy. Consider:

- shortly after taking office, Reagan ended the grain embargo against the Soviet Union, put in place by Jimmy Carter to protest the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan;
- on October 23, 1983, 241 Americans (including an Annapolis classmate of mine) died in a terror attack on our Marine barracks in Beirut, and the very next day Reagan invaded a medical school on a Caribbean island;
- in speech after speech Reagan promised he would never negotiate with terrorists, but in 1985 his national security apparatus sold weapons to the Iranians (who had taken our embassy staff hostage 6 years earlier), in order to gain the release of 7 Americans held hostage in Lebanon, and used the proceeds of those weapons sales to terrorists to fund weapons for the rebel group in Nicaragua, in clear violation of law.

But tell us more about Reagan's firm foreign policy. Those of us who lived through those times are eager to hear.
They know one thing they WILL NOT do. That is, go into another stupid and needless war.
The decline was actually started by your President Bush when he enmroiled the US in a decade long needless wars.

So true. Sad but true.
Good column.

Why do you think that the world needs the US to intervene in foreign countries ?........ The world sees the US wars in Vietnam, Iraq and the push by the AIPACers ,who control Congress to, start a war with Iran as not helpful or needed.
The world needs U.S. Presidents who will be believed when they threaten to intervene, and, at present, it doesn't have one.

As Commander in Chief, President Obama could have, should have, ordered the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Afghanistan in January 2009. Instead he ordered an escalation of the war. He bombed Libya. He tried to bomb Syria, but was thwarted with the help of Progressives and Libertarians. He continues to use the CIA, NED and USAID to destabilize foreign governments he does not like.

"Five years of peace"?  I doubt that many Yemenis, Pakistanis, or Somalis would describe as "peace" the last five years of massive escalation in illegal and cowardly attacks by unmanned U.S. aircraft on the poorest of the poor in far-flung corners of the world.
Obama is the one who advocates for keeping tens of thousands of US soldiers in Afghanistan for another decade.  That doesn't sound like a peacenik to me.

The Obama approach to foreign policy is wise and calibrated. He has ended two foolish wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

Obama recognizes that modern war is expensive in money and international prestige. The lessons of the Bush era have yet to be learned -- wars drain the national budget, divert resources from critical needs, and fail to achieve the goals.

There are no issues that threaten U.S. national security today. At the same time, there will always be people seeking to drag us into dumb adventures. it takes a wise President to resist the temptation to react to the news event of the moment -- whether in Syrian, Nigeria, Ukraine, or Israel.

Obama's effort to pivot resources to Asia is smart and farsighted. His belief in working in consort with allies ("leading from behind") is realistic. Most of all, he understands that power flows from a strong domestic condition -- good health insurance, education, energy diversity, middle class security, and sound infrastructure.

The U.S. has had five years of peace under Obama. He has closed out the two brutal Bush wars. Only a foolish public would take such benefits for granted.

Obama advocates proportionate response.  You don't crush an ant with a sledge hammer.  And you don't try to stop a dinosaur with sewing needles.  When you espouse grandiose principles and seek to enforce your will without regard for proportionality, you end up using deadly force without just cause.  This leads to the sacrifice of American lives in furtherance of lofty goals in pursuits that are misguided and/or wrongful and sometimes foolish.  You all know what I'm talking about.

A firm foreign policy like arming the soon to be Taliban, arming Saddam Hussein, funding slaughter in Nicaragua, Honduras, El Salvador, genocide in Guatemala and invading Grenada?
In the process raising the debt ceiling 17 times in 96 months, every 5.6 months?
The day Reagan took office the US was the worlds' largest creditor, eight miserable years later the US was the worlds' largest debtor.
That was strong?

Joel:

The Economist's Ryan Avent wrote yesterday: "In [this] way, and in many others, this does look quite a lot like the Reinhart-Rogoff contretemps, to which Mr Giles draws a parallel. The errors identified in their spreadsheet turned out to be far more embarrassing to the authors than a threat to their work. The attack on the Reinhart-Rogoff analysis showed that the authors had made a mistake in the figures that led them to identify a "discontinuity" in growth rates when public debt reaches a 90% of GDP threshold. But the analysis by economists at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst actually reinforced the finding that growth rates tended to be slower when debt levels were higher. The UMass work did nothing to undermine the broad dataset that rested beneath the 90% work (and beneath their book, and many other pieces of research). Subsequent analyses have turned up a discontinuity at various thresholds (though other papers have not)."

Ironically, Obama's foreign policy mirrors that of Bush and to a lesser extent Clinton. The focus is solely to benefit special interests/corporations at the expense of the domestic economy. Special interests, the wealthy and politicians have no need to concern themselves with jobs, healthcare or shelter. They have all 3 in abundance beyond the absurd while average America has hit rock bottom and all the Walmarts, Amazons and McDonalds cannot stem the tide with low wage employment. America was sold to China so corporate America, the wealthy & elite and corrupt politicians could get "theirs" at the expense of the masses. Average Americans, unlike politcos, don't get special invitation "speaking engagements" in Dubai, Hong Kong and wherever else the "thank you" money for politicians is paid off. They carry the country on their backs because they're stupid and powerless. Ironically, those that now complain the most are those that have been crafting foreign policy for the last 2 decades through whispers, winks & nods and legislation that enables the wholesale selling off of America. Those that can effect change are the ones that brought us here in the first place, meaning we are lost and the obvious will soon loom on the horizon, and it won't be pretty.
Try getting an army together in America in the next decade to fight off China, Russia or anyone else the elite & corporations deem the enemy. Good luck with that.

What was Vietnam, Iraq, & Afghanistan (among many since WWII) if not "a huge military failure"[s]?  Those failures do appear to me to have resulted in any questioning of the assumptions that led to these disasters in the first place.

The US already interferes a lot in the rest of the world.. it does not have to use overt military force to show that....So the fact is wether it is Obama or any other President... US power is based on it's global military reach and that will continue till it faces a huge military or economic failure.

No doubt he is "concerned" about the state of affairs in the world and "confident" that his "speech" will fix things so that America remains the one nation defending liberty and freedom around the world with freshly printed money, and an economy of the 1% for the 1% by the 1% at home.

What Obama supporters do not realize is that even Obama has not relinquished the interventionist policy of the US to maintain it's global hegemony and in turn it's economic power. The only difference is that he has overly relied on covert operations to achieve his goals. That might fool the american public, but most of the world see through it and relizes that the US is the same.

The domestic critics of Obama yearn for the Cheney/Bush foreign policy. The will be satisfied only when the world is recast in their image, and in the name of freedom support the enrichment of their cronies and ideological shipmates.
I wouldn't be listening to anyone that insists on referring to the President as "O".

Non-Republicans have allowed Republicans to frame just about every significant debate in the U.S. for the last 30 years.  It less an "Obama issue" than it is an issue of corporate America being in control of how important issues are discussed and what is left off the table.

LOL. You are making something out of absolutely nothing. Calling President Barack Obama O is just shorthand, like calling President George W. Bush W or President Franklin Delano Roosevelt FDR (can't call him BO). It has no significance at all and wasn't meant to have any significance. BTW, if you look at his actual signature, it is dominated by a big round O. If there is some significance that you perceive, I'd be curious to know what it is.

Almost six years into his Presidency and O still thinks that if he just goes about being President the American people will figure out on their own what he is doing and why he is doing it, as if that is all self-evident. Well, it's not. A leader has to tell the troops where they are going. Instead of communicating with the American people he lets the Republicans frame the debate and only steps forward when they succeed in making him look bad. O still has a lot to learn about how this business of government works.

President Obama is going to lay out a retooled foreign policy agenda. What number speech is this? 975?
We've already seen Obama's Syria agenda. Anything he does now will be way too late.
First, Obama said that if he had evidence that chemical weapons would be used he would conduct limited strategic strikes. He even boasted that he didn't need Congress' approval,
He said that Assad must go and he even talked of arming the rebels.
France was the only country who supported Obama's threat and then suddenly, Obama pivoted and said he would go to Congress. To me, this was for a very simple reason. If Congress would shoot him down, and they would, then he could paint them the bad guy and say he tried. And he hesitated so long to arm the rebels that many of them had become aligned with al Qaeda, the very al Qaeda that Obama decimated and was on the run, according to him.
Now, the rebels are clearly on their heels, there have been several more chemical weapons attacks and there are now 170,000 dead including 8,000 children. And that number will continue to grow.
Obama made empty threats repeatedly and Putin called his bluff. He knew full well that Obama would do nothing so all this posturing by Ben Rhodes that they are leading is laughable.
Did anyone see the interview with Putin yesterday? He openly mocked Obama and said maybe he should get another job.
There is nothing that Obama can do do to restore our prestige. That ship has sailed and he was not on it.

Ahhh yes! Speak loudly and wave a soft twig. Lead from behind!

See Libya (ex-Benghazi) and mourn for Syria under his watch. Watch Ukraine after the "reset" with Russia, and China after the "pivot" to Asia! All done while extending the velvet glowed hand around the world that believe in fists because it does not fear another "speech".

I doubt if the quality of political discussion or education was higher in 1950. Certainly it was not on matters racial. It might have been higher in economics, since the positive role governments could play, as sketched by Keynes, was appreciated by most.

High re-election rates combined with low approval rates does not mean political ignorance; many politically sophisticated people feel the same way. It means that the system is broken, so that well-meaning and competent people cannot use it to work together and achieve results. And since the system is broken, it is no use in the task of figuring out how to fix it. The way we would fix the broken system is to use the system that is broken.

The broken system serves those who control the political and bureaucratic class. Since politicians and bureaucrats need private sector contacts and jobs to make any decent (for the private sector) amount of money, they do not challenge the system except in ineffective ways.

I'm not sure it's an ethical question at all. But for an important example of using pseudonyms to influence the way a written argument is received, look at "The Federalist Papers."
Or, to go from the sublime to the ridiculous, look at most of the comments posted on the Internet.
